critique: This document establishes a wildlife refuge in Washington state. It transfers land acquired under previous acts to the Department of Agriculture for this purpose. The order prohibits hunting, trapping, or disturbing wildlife within the refuge, subject to regulations by the Secretary of Agriculture. It also amends previous executive orders to exclude the refuge area from their provisions. The document itself doesn't directly address ideological issues, immigration, or civil liberties. It expands executive power insofar as it sets aside land and restricts activities within the refuge, but this is a fairly standard exercise of executive authority in land management. It centralizes control of the land in the federal government. It has a slight positive impact on social inclusion by protecting wildlife.
